[[File:Civil Right Agenda.JPG|thumb|Members of the Sikh Coalition (2008)]] '''Sapreet Kaur Saluja''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leadershipdirectories.com/profiles/Sapreet-Saluja-Dir-National-Board-of-Directors-Girl-Scouts-.htm|title= Sapreet Kaur Saluja - Leadership Profile|publisher=Leadership Directories|accessdate=5 September 2015 |language=}}</ref> usually known as '''Sapreet Kaur''' {{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}, (born on May 7, 1976) is an American civil rights activist who since September 2009 has been executive director of the [[Sikh Coalition]] in the United States.<ref name=sikhsindia>{{cite web|url=http://sikhsindia.blogspot.lu/2009/09/sapreet-kaur-named-executive-director.html|title=Sapreet Kaur named Executive Director of Sikh Coalition |publisher=Sikhs India - Online Sikh News Channel|date=23 September 2009|accessdate=4 September 2015 |language=}}</ref> In January 2013, she became the first [[Sikh]] to speak at a [[Second inauguration of Barack Obama#National prayer service|Presidential Inaugural Prayer Service]] in [[Washington D.C.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhcoalition.org/advisories/2013/making-history-inaugural-prayer-service-includes-first-sikh-speaker|title=Executive Director Sapreet Kaur Becomes First Sikh to Offer Prayer at Presidential Inaugural Prayer Service |publisher=The Sikh Coalition|accessdate=4 September 2015 |language=}}</ref>
==Biography== Saluja was born and raised in central [[New Jersey]] where her parents had arrived from [[Punjab]] in the 1960s.<ref name=beast>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/witw/articles/2014/04/23/sikh-coalition-s-sapreet-kaur-on-learning-from-being-different.html|title=Learning From Being Different|publisher=The Daily Beast|date=23 April 2014|accessdate=4 September 2015 |language=}}</ref><ref name=scappoint/> She went to the Sikh-oriented Khalsa School in [[Bridgewater Township, New Jersey|Bridgewater, New Jersey]], regularly attending [[Camp Chardi Kala]] in the summer months. In 1998, she graduated in marketing and international business at [[New York University]]'s [[Stern School of Business]].<ref name=sikhsindia/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pub/sapreet-kaur-saluja/88/ba8/755|title=Sapreet Kaur Saluja|publisher=Linkedin|accessdate=4 September 2015 |language=}}</ref>
After graduating, Kaur served as a volunteer in the [[United States Peace Corps]] in Kenya and Uganda (1998–2001), creating local programs in the areas of conservation, conflict resolution and organizational development. Thereafter she worked in management positions at [[Coach, Inc.]] and at [[Teach for America]] where she developed human capital leadership strategies for work aimed at overcoming inequity in education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhamericanchamber.org/sikh-women-as-business-leaders-panelists-bio|title=Sikh Women as Business Leaders - Panelists Bio|publisher=Sikh American Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=5 September 2015 |language=}}</ref>
In 2007, Kaur became a member of the board of directors of the Sikh Coalition where she was appointed executive director in 2009. Since 2014, she has served as international commissioner for the National Board of Directors.<ref name=leadership>{{cite web|url=http://www.sikharts.com/leadership-summit_2014_kaur.html|title=Sapreet Kaur|publisher=Sikh Leadership Summit 2014|accessdate=4 September 2015 |language=}}</ref> On her appointment as executive director, Kaur became the first woman to have led a Sikh civil rights organization in the United States. In her own words, her goal has been to bring the full force of all our program areas, partner organizations and volunteers across the country to defend the rights of Sikhs to fearlessly practice our faith".<ref name=scappoint>{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhcoalition.org/advisories/2009/coalition-appoints-new-executive-director|title=Sikh Coalition Appoints Seasoned Non-Profit Leader Sapreet Kaur as Executive Director |publisher=The Sikh Coalition|date=22 September 2009|accessdate=5 September 2015 |language=}}</ref>
Kaur is serving as a board member of the [[World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts]] (2008–2014) and is a member of the [[Desmond Tutu Peace Foundation]] board of directors.<ref name=leadership/>
Sapreet Kaur has a son, Zoraver Singh (born 2010).<ref name=beast/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhchic.com/article-detail.php?cat=31&id=2807|title=My First Sikh Books|author=Kaur Saluja, Sapreet|publisher=sikhchic.com|accessdate=5 September 2015 |language=}}</ref>

'''Sharan Kaur Pabla''' was a [[Sikh]] martyr who was slain in 1705 by [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] soldiers while cremating the bodies two older sons of [[Guru Gobind Singh]], the 10th Sikh Guru, after the [[Battle of Chamkaur]]. She was from the village Raipur Rani which is 2 km from the famous town of [[Chamkaur]].<ref name ="DK Varma">The Battle of Chamkaur (22 December 1705), The Panjab past and present, Volume 20, pp 276, Devinder Kumar Varma, Punjabi University. Dept. of Punjab Historical Studies, 1986</ref><ref name = "Nanuan">Saini jagata utapati ate wikasa , pp 50, pp 72 , pp 101, Surajita Singha Nanua, Patiala : Manajota Prakashana, ਪਟਿਆਲਾ : ਮਨਜੋਤ ਪ੍ਰਕਾਸ਼ਨ, 2008, DK Agencies DKPAN-5413 ( HBD )</ref>
Guru Gobind Singh escaped the fort of Chamkaur on the night of December 22, 1705. He briefly stopped at Raipur on his way to [[Machhiwara]]. Here he asked a lady by the name of Bibi Sharan Kaur Pabla to perform the last rites of the martyred Sikhs, which included two of Guru Gobind Singh's own sons, [[Sahibzada Ajit Singh]] and [[Sahibzada Jujhar Singh]] . [[Bibi Sharan Kaur Pabla]] performed the last rites of the two elder Sahibzadas and other Sikh warriors who had laid down their lives in the battle. According to one account, Bibi Sharan Kaur Pabla was so grief-stricken that she herself jumped in the funeral pyre and ended her life. According to another view she did not self-immolate but was slain by Moghul soldiers and thrown in the funeral pyre of Sahibzadas, when she and her other accomplices from Raipur, were caught cremating the bodies of Sahibzadas.<ref name ="DK Varma"/>
A third account says that she indeed jump into funeral pyre in a [[Jauhar]] style self-immolation. Her own husband Bhai Pritam Singh, who was one of Guru Gobind Singh's warriors, was with the 10th Guru inside the Chamkaur fort resisting the Moghul attack. She discovered her husband among the dead. In total she is said to have collected bodies of thirty two stormtroopers of the Guru, including two Sahibzadas. She tried to cremate them in a single funeral pyre. As soon as the funeral pyre was lit she was discovered by [[Moghul]] and [[Ranghar]] soldiers who wanted the bodies of the soldiers - martyrs according to Sikh tradition- to rot in open air in order to terrorise non-Muslim population who refused to apostasize or give out the whereabouts of Guru Gobind Singh. It is said that understanding the intentions of the Moghul soldiers to outrage her modesty, she jumped into the funeral pyre of Sikh warriors, which included her own husband, to save her honour.<ref>[http://www.rajkaregakhalsa.com/Bibi-Sharan-Kaur-Jee.htm Bibi Sharan Kaur's martyrdom as per Sikh accounts]</ref>
Sharan Kaur was a [[Saini]] and Raipur has considerable [[Saini]] population. She is also sometimes linked as a possible ancestor with Sikh nobleman of Phulkiyan, Sardar [[Nanu Singh Saini]], whose family later owned sizeable land in the village Raipur.<ref name = "Nanuan"/> This village also has the funerary shrines or 'smadhs' of the following Sikh martyrs: Jathedar Naunihal Singh, Mastan Singh, Santokh Singh and Malkiat Singh. In 1945 a Gurudwara was built in village Raipur to commemorate Bibi Sharan Kaur Pabla.<ref name = "Nanuan"/>
==Jamrud and Lahore Espionage== Once she was sent to find out the strength of the Pathan forces that were conspiring to ambush Jamrud. She kept a concealed identity. She had some very secret information regarding the attack for the Pathan chief and was arranging a meeting in which she explained him the conspiracy and her brother brutal killing. The chief thanked her and assured her against the Sikhs. She managed to use her handkerchief to press it to his nose. She killed him with dagger very silently and managed to escape from the sword of soldiers.
Hari Singh Nalwa, the Sikh ruler, became serious due to ailment at Jamrud. Pathans took advantage of the situation and revolted and surrounded the fort to attack. It was pretended that he was healing and taken to fort top where he was shown walking to demoralise the rebels. But on 30 April 1837, he died. His demise was still a secret. Sharan Kaur showed her bravery by disguising herself as a Pathan woman and got to Pashawar to inform Maharaja Ranjit Singh about this incident.
By her such information Maharaja Ranjit Singh took hold of the situation and squelched the rebel with his large force. She saved the fort. Sharan Kaur was later awarded and thanked for her bravery. She will always be remembered for her selfless service and excellent espionage in the pages of history.<ref>https://www.allaboutsikhs.com/great-sikh-women/bibi-sharan-kaur</ref>

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Inari-Jogyo-ji.jpg|thumb|[[Kitsune|Foxes]] sacred to Shinto kami [[Inari Ōkami|Inari]], a ''[[torii]]'', a Buddhist [[tō|stone pagoda]], and Buddhist figures together at Jōgyō-ji, [[Kamakura, Kanagawa|Kamakura]]]] '''''Shinbutsu-shūgō''''' ({{lang|ja|神仏習合}}, "syncretism of kami and buddhas"), also called '''Shinbutsu-konkō''' ({{lang|ja|神仏混淆}}, "jumbling up" or "contamination of kami and buddhas"), is the [[syncretism]] of [[Buddhism in Japan|Buddhism]] and [[kami]] worship that was Japan's only organized religion up until the [[Meiji period]]. Beginning in 1868, the new Meiji government approved a series of laws that separated Japanese native kami worship, on one side, from Buddhism which had assimilated it, on the other.<ref>See [[Shinbutsu bunri]]</ref>
When Buddhism was introduced from [[China]] in the [[Asuka period]] (6th century), rather than discarding the old belief system, the Japanese tried to reconcile the two, assuming both were true. As a consequence, [[Buddhist temples in Japan|Buddhist temples]] ({{lang|ja|寺}}, ''tera'') were [[Jingū-ji|attached]] to local [[Shinto shrine]]s ({{lang|ja|神社}}, ''jinja'') and vice versa and devoted to both [[kami]] and [[buddhahood|buddhas]]. The local religion and foreign Buddhism never quite fused, but remained however inextricably linked all the way to the present day, always interacting. The depth of the resulting influence of Buddhism on local religious beliefs can be seen for example in the fact that much of Shinto's conceptual vocabulary and even the types of Shinto shrines we see today, with a large worship hall and religious images, are themselves of Buddhist origin.<ref>See for example the article [[Shinto architecture]]</ref><ref name="Tamura21">Tamura, page 21</ref> The formal [[Shinbutsu bunri|separation of Buddhism from Shinto]] took place only as recently as the end of the 19th century; however, in many ways, the blending of the two still continues.<ref name="sueki2"/>
The term ''shinbutsu shūgō'' itself was coined during the early modern era (17th century) to refer to the amalgamation of kami and ''buddhas'' in general, as opposed to specific currents within Buddhism which did the same, e.g. Ryōbu Shintō and Sannō Shintō.<ref name=inoue>Inoue (2004:67-68)</ref> The term may have a negative connotation of bastardization and randomness.<ref>Teeuwen & Rambelli (2002:49)</ref>
==Assimilation of Buddhism==
===Debate over the nature of Shinto=== There is no agreement among specialists as to the exact extent of fusion between the two religions.<ref name="BT4"/>
According to some scholars, for example Hirai Naofusa, in Japan, and [[Joseph Kitagawa]], in the US, Shinto is the indigenous religion of Japan, has existed as such continuously since pre-history, and consists of all the peculiarly Japanese rituals and beliefs shaped by Japanese history from prehistory to the present.<ref name="BT4"/> The term "Shinto" itself was coined in the 6th century to differentiate the loosely organized local religion from imported Buddhism.<ref name="KG139">Kitagawa (1987:139)</ref>
The opposing view belongs to Japanese historian [[Toshio Kuroda]] (and his supporters) who, in a famous article ("Shinto in the History of Japanese Religion," published in English in 1981<ref>[http://www.univie.ac.at/rel_jap/k/images/0/03/Kuroda_1981.pdf KURODA TOSHIO, Shinto in the History of Japanese Religion, Translated by JAMES C. DOBBINS and SUZANNE GAY, Journal of Japanese Studies, 7-1, 1981]</ref>), has argued that Shinto as an independent religion was born only in the modern period after emerging in the Middle Ages as an offshoot of Buddhism.<ref name="BT4">Breen and Teeuwen in ''Breen and Teeuwen'' (2000:4-5)</ref><ref name="rambelli">Rambelli (2001)</ref> Kuroda's main argument is that Shinto as a distinct religion is a Meiji era invention of Japanese nationalist ideologues (see the section [[#Buddhism_and_Shinto_after_the_Separation_Order|The two religions after the Separation Order]] below).<ref name="BT4"/> He points out how the state formalization of ''[[kami]]'' rituals and the state ranking of shrines during the [[Heian period]] were not the emergence of Shinto as an independent religion, but an effort to explain local beliefs in Buddhist terms.<ref name="BT4"/> He also says that, while it is true that the two characters for "Shinto" appear very early in the historical record, for example in the [[Nihon Shoki]], this does not mean today's Shinto already existed as a religion because they were originally used as a name for [[Taoism]] or even for religion in general.<ref name="BT4"/> Indeed, according to Kuroda, many features of Shinto, for example the worshiping of mirrors and swords or the very structure of the [[Ise Shrine]] (Shinto's holiest and most important site) are typical of Taoism.<ref name="BT4"/> The term Shinto in old texts therefore does not necessarily indicate something uniquely Japanese.
Still according to this view, Shinto's rise as an autonomous religion was gradual and started to become evident with the emergence of [[Yoshida Kanetomo]]'s [[Yoshida Shintō]]. The term Shinto started to be used with today's meaning of ''kami'' worship only later during the [[Edo period]].<ref name="Grundbegriffe:Shinto">{{cite web|last=[[Bernhard Scheid|Scheid, Bernhard]]|title=Trennung von Shinto und Buddhismus|url=http://www.univie.ac.at/rel_jap/an/Grundbegriffe:Shinto|work=Grundbegriffe:Shinto|publisher=University of Vienna|accessdate=31 October 2010}}</ref> During the same era, [[Kokugaku]] theorists like [[Motoori Norinaga]] tried to separate it intellectually from Buddhism, preparing the ground for the final schism of the [[Meiji Restoration]].
According to the first view, then, the two religions were at the time of their first meeting already formed and independent and thereafter just coexisted with non-essential exchanges. According to the second, Buddhism, meeting local kami beliefs in Japan, actually produced today's Shinto.<ref name="sueki2">Sueki (2007:2)</ref><ref name="rambelli"/><ref name="Kur7">Kuroda (1981:7)</ref><ref name="ANHS">{{cite book|last=John Breen|first=Mark Teeuwen|title=A new History of Shinto|year=2010|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-1-4051-5516-8|pages=221|url=https://www.amazon.com/History-Shinto-Blackwell-Histories-Religion/dp/1405155167}}</ref>
===Assimilation process=== The fusion of Buddhism with the local kami worship started as soon as the first arrived in Japan. [[Mononobe clan|Mononobe]] no Okoshi wrote, "The kami of our land will be offended if we worship a foreign kami."<ref name="Tamura">Tamura, pages 26 to 33.</ref> Mononobe saw [[Gautama Buddha]] as just another kami.<ref name="Tamura"/> Foreign kami were called {{nihongo|''banshin''|蕃神|"barbarian gods"}} or {{nihongo|''busshin''|仏神|"Buddhist gods"}}, and understood to be more or less like local ones.<ref name="coka"/> Initially, therefore, the conflict between the two religions was political, and not religious, in nature, a struggle between the progressive [[Soga clan]], that wanted a more international outlook for the country, and the conservative [[Mononobe clan]], that wanted the contrary.<ref name="Tamura"/>
Buddhism was not passive in the assimilation process, but was itself ready to assimilate and be assimilated. By the time it entered Japan it was already syncretic, having adapted to and amalgamated with other religions and cultures in India, China, and the [[Korean Peninsula]].<ref name="coka">Encyclopedia of Shinto, [http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=190 Combinatory Kami], accessed on October 13, 2008. Quotation: "Buddhism was already product of a complex process of adaptation and amalgamation with other belief systems in India, China, and the Korean peninsula."</ref> For example, already while in India, it had absorbed Hindu divinities like [[Brahma]] (''Bonten'' in Japanese) and [[Indra]] (''Taishakuten'').<ref name="coka"/> When it arrived in Japan, it already had a disposition towards producing the combinatory gods that the Japanese would call {{nihongo|shūgōshin|習合神|syncretic gods}}.<ref name="coka"/> Searching for the origins of a kami in Buddhist scriptures was felt to be nothing out of the ordinary.<ref name="coka"/>
However, if monks didn't doubt the existence of kami, they certainly saw them as inferior to their buddhas.<ref name="sheid">Bernhard Scheid</ref> Hindu gods had already been treated analogously: they had been thought of as un-illuminated and prisoners of ''[[saṃsāra]]''.<ref name="sheid"/> Buddhist claims of superiority encountered resistance, and monks tried to overcome them by deliberately integrating kami into their system.<ref name="sheid"/> Several strategies to do this were developed and deployed.<ref name="sheid"/>
The process of amalgamation is usually divided into three stages.<ref name="BT95">Mark Teeuwen in ''Breen and Teeuwen'' (2000:95-96)</ref>
The first articulation of the difference between Japanese religious ideas and Buddhism, and the first effort to reconcile the two is attributed to [[Prince Shōtoku]] (574 - 622), and the first signs that the differences between the two world views were beginning to become manifest to the Japanese in general appear at the time of [[Emperor Tenmu]] (673 - 86).<ref name="Tamura"/> Accordingly, one of the first efforts to reconcile Shinto and Buddhism was made in the 8th century during the [[Nara period]] founding so-called {{nihongo|''[[jingū-ji]]''|神宮寺}}, that is ''shrine-temples'', complexes comprising both a shrine and a temple.<ref name="BT95"/><ref name="EoS">Satō Makoto</ref>
Behind the inclusion in a [[Shinto shrine]] of Buddhist religious objects was the idea that the kami were [[Deva (Buddhism)|lost beings in need of liberation]] through Buddhism like any other [[Sentient beings (Buddhism)|sentient beings]].<ref name="EoS"/> Kami were thought to be subject to [[karma]] and reincarnation like human beings, and early Buddhist stories tell how the task of helping suffering kami was assumed by wandering monks.<ref name="sheid"/> A local kami would appear in a dream to the monk, telling him about his suffering.<ref name="sheid"/> To improve the kami's karma through rites and the reading of [[sutra]]s, [[Bhikkhu|Buddhist monks]] would build temples next to kami shrines.<ref name="sheid"/> Such groupings had been created by the 7th century, for example at [[Usa Jingū]] in [[Kyushu|Kyūshū]],<ref name="sheid"/> where [[Hachiman]] was worshiped together with [[Maitreya]]. The building of temples at shrines produced [[Jingū-ji|shrine-temple]] complexes, which in turn accelerated the amalgamation process.<ref name="BT95"/> As a result of the creation of shrine-temple complexes, many shrines that had until then been just an open-air site became Buddhist style groupings of buildings.<ref name="NHoS">{{cite book|last=Breen, Teeuwen|title=A New History of Shinto|year=2010|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |isbn=978-1-4051-5516-8|pages=39}}</ref>
At the end of the same century, in what is considered the second stage of the amalgamation, the kami Hachiman was declared a [[dharmapala]] and, later, a [[bodhisattva]].<ref name="BT95"/> Shrines for him started to be built at temples (the so-called "[[Chinjusha|temple-shrines]]"), marking an important step ahead in the process of amalgamation of kami and Buddhism.<ref name="BT95"/> When the great buddha at [[Tōdai-ji]] in [[Nara, Nara|Nara]] was built, there was also erected within the temple grounds a shrine for Hachiman – according to the legend because of a wish expressed by the kami himself.<ref name="sheid"/> Hachiman considered this his reward for having helped the temple find the gold and copper mines from which the metal for the great statue had come.<ref name="sheid"/> After this, temples in the entire country adopted tutelary [[kami]] ({{nihongo|chinju|鎮守/鎮主}}.<ref name="BT95"/>
===''Honji suijaku'' theory=== {{main article|Honji suijaku}} The third and final stage of the fusion took place in the 9th century with the development of the {{nihongo|''[[honji suijaku]]''|本地垂迹}} theory according to which Japanese kami are emanations of [[buddhahood|buddha]]s, ''bodhisattvas'' or [[deva (Buddhism)|deva]]s who mingle with human beings to lead them to the Buddhist Way.<ref name="BT95"/> This theory was the keystone of the whole ''shinbutsu shūgō'' edifice and therefore the foundation of Japanese religion for many centuries. Because of it, most kami changed from potentially dangerous spirits to be improved through contact with the Buddhist law to local emanations of buddhas and bodhisattvas which possess a wisdom of their own.<ref name="BT95"/> Buddhas and kami were now indivisible twins.<ref name="EoS"/>
The status of kami however changed dramatically according to the sect. At one extreme one was [[Shingon Buddhism]]'s [[Muromachi period#Shinto|Ryōbu Shintō]] thinkers, who considered kami and buddhas equivalent in power and dignity.<ref name="scheid2">Scheid, Shinto im Mittelalter</ref> However, not all kami were emanations of some buddha. Some, often called {{nihongo|''jitsu no kami''|実神|true kami}}, usually dangerous and angry, had no Buddhist counterpart. Among them were the ''[[tengu]]'', or animals possessing magic, as the [[fox]] (''[[kitsune]]'') or {{nihongo|[[Japanese raccoon dog#In folklore and tradition|Japanese raccoon dog]]|狸|tanuki}}. Even these unholy and inferior "true kami" however attracted the attention of Ryōbu Shinto thinkers, which resulted in theories which declared them to be manifestations of [[Vairocana]] and [[Amaterasu]].<ref name="scheid2"/>
On the other hand, [[Pure Land Buddhism]] was somewhat different because it at first renounced kami-worship due to the notion that kami were inferior to the buddhas. <ref name="scheid2"/> However, the largest Pure Land branch, Jōdo Shinshū, still encouraged the worship of kami despite the fact that faith in Amida Buddha should be the primary practice. Furthermore, under the influence of Rennyo and other leaders, Jōdo Shinshū accepted the mainstream honji suijaku beliefs and the spiritual relationship between kami and the buddhas and bodhisattvas. <ref>Kenneth Doo Lee (2007), ''The Prince and the Monk: Shotoku Worship in Shinran's Buddhism''; James C. Dobbins (1989), ''Jodo Shinshu: Shin Buddhism in Medieval Japan'', pp. 142-143.</ref>
===Shinbutsu kakuri=== {{main article|Shinbutsu kakuri}}
The two religions however never fused completely and, while overlapping here and there, kept their particular identity within a difficult, largely un-systematized and tense relationship.<ref name="sueki7">Sueki (2007:7-8)</ref> This relationship existed, rather than between two systems, between particular kami and particular buddhas.<ref name="sueki7"/> The two were always perceived as parallel but separate entities.<ref name="ramte"/> Besides ''shinbutsu shūgō'' there was always the other side of the coin of continued separation.<ref name="sueki7"/>
In fact, the term {{nihongo|''shinbutsu kakuri''|神仏隔離|isolation of "[[kami]]" from [[Buddhism]]}} in Japanese Buddhist terminogy refers to the tendency that existed in Japan to keep some kami separate from Buddhism.<ref name="ramte">Rambelli and Teeuwen (2002:21-22)</ref> While some kami were integrated in Buddhism, others (or at times even the same kami in a different context) were kept systematically away from Buddhism.<ref name="ramte"/> This phenomenon had significant consequences for Japanese culture as a whole.<ref name="ramte"/> It must not be confused with ''[[shinbutsu bunri]]'' ("separation of kami and buddhas") or with ''[[haibutsu kishaku]]'' ("abolish buddhas and destroy Shākyamuni"), which are phenomena recurrent in Japanese history and usually due to political causes. While the first assumes the acceptance of Buddhism, the second and third actually oppose it.
The practice had in any case important consequences, among them the prevention of the complete assimilation of kami practices into Buddhism.<ref name="ramte"/> Also, the prohibition of Buddhism at the Ise and [[Kamo Shrine]]s allowed them to freely develop their theories about the nature of kami.<ref name="ramte"/>
== Buddhism and Shinto after the Separation Order == {{main article|Shinbutsu bunri}} During the ''[[Shinbutsu bunri]]'', the attempt to separate Shinto from Buddhism, temples and shrines were forcefully separated by law with the {{nihongo|"Kami and Buddhism Separation Order"|神仏判然令|Shinbutsu Hanzenrei}} of 1868.
However, in spite of more than a century of formal separation of the two religions, temples or shrines that do not separate them are still common, as proven for example by the existence of some important Buddhist [[Inari shrine]]s.<ref>[http://www.toyokawa-map.net/eng/inari.html Toyokawa Inari] accessed on June 6, 2008</ref> During the Meiji period, in order to help the spread of Shinto, [[Jingū-ji|shrine-temples]] (''jingū-ji'') were destroyed while [[Chinjusha|temple-shrines]] (''chinjusha'') were tolerated. As a result, shrine-temples are now rare (an extant example is [[Seiganto-ji]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Jungūji|url=http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1126|publisher=Encyclopedia of Shinto|accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref>), but temple-shrines are common, and most temples still have at least a small one.<ref name="BT7">Breen and Teeuwen in ''Breen and Teeuwen'' (2000:7)</ref>
Prominent religious institutions in both camps still give evidence of integration of the two religions. The great [[Kenchō-ji]] temple, number one of the [[Kamakura]]'s great [[Zen]] temples (the [[Five Mountain System]]) includes two shrines. One of the islands in the right-side pond of [[Tsurugaoka Hachimangū]] in Kamakura hosts a subshrine dedicated to goddess [[Benzaiten]], a form of [[Saraswati]].<ref name="Kamiya18"/> For this reason, the sub-shrine was removed in 1868 at the time of the ''Shinbutsu Bunri'', but rebuilt in 1956.<ref name="Kamiya18">Kamiya (2008: 18 - 19)</ref>
Shinto and Buddhism still have a symbiotic relationship of interdependence, particularly concerning funeral rites (entrusted to Buddhism) and [[Marriage in Japan|weddings]] (usually left to Shinto or sometimes Christianity). The separation of the two religions is therefore considered only superficial, and ''shinbutsu shūgō'' is still an accepted practice.
Still, the separation of the two religions is felt to be real by the public. Scholar Karen Smyers comments, "The surprise of many of my informants regarding the existence of Buddhist Inari temples shows the success of the government's attempt to create separate conceptual categories regarding sites and certain identities, although practice remains multiple and nonexclusive".<ref>Smyers, pag. 219</ref>

'''Shyam Manohar Goswami''' ([[IAST]]: Śyāma Manohara Gosvāmī, [[Hindi]]: श्याम मनोहर गोस्वामी, [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]]: શ્યામ મનોહર ગોસ્વામી) also known as '''Shyamu Bava''' ([[IAST]]: Śyāmu Bāvā, [[Hindi]]: शयामू बावा, [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]]: શ્યામુ બાવા), is the 16th [[Lineal descendant|descendent]] of Shri [[Vallabha Acharya]], sanskritists, [[philosopher]], [[spiritual leader]], active reformer & [[guru]] of the [[Krishna]]-centered [[Pushtimarg]] sect of [[Vaishnavism]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Shyamdas Recognized in Pushti Publication|url=https://www.shyamdasfoundation.com/shyamdas-recognized-in-pushti-publication/|website=shyamdasfoundation.com|publisher=Shyamdasfoundation|accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sahoo|first1=Ajaya Kumar|title=Indian Transnationalism Online: New Perspectives on Diaspora|date=February 28, 2014|publisher=Ashgate (February 28, 2014)|isbn=1472419138|page=233}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=A Storm of Songs|date=2015|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Acknowledgements|isbn=9780674425286|edition=Harvard University Press, 2015|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eMDFCQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT7&ots=tHRh1N9XAD&dq=shyam%20manohar%20goswami%20McGill%20University&pg=PT7#v=onepage&q=shyam%20manohar%20goswami%20McGill%20University&f=false|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref>.
==Life==
===Childhood=== Shyam Manohar Goswami was born in Mumbai, India. His father Goswami Shri Dikshitji Maharaj was a well renowned [[Pushtimarg]] [[guru]], was the 15th [[Lineal descendant|descendent]] of Shri [[Vallabha Acharya]]. <!-- ===Education===
===Personal life=== --> ==Academia & Research== [[File:Shyam Manohar Goswami giving lecture at IPC 2017.jpg|right|thumb|225px|Shyam Manohar Goswami giving lecture at the Indian philosophical congress, Sanchi University of Buddhist-Indic Studies - 2017]] <!--Shyam Manohar Goswami is actively teaching the course of Vallabh Vedanta at the University of Mumbai.[Need citation]--> Shyam Manohar Goswami presided over the national seminar on ''Vaishnav contribution to Kashi'' in 2001<ref>{{cite web|title=Vaishnava Contribution to Kashi|url=http://www.jnanapravaha.org/event-details.php?evid=30&pid=1&sid=3&t=&pg=5|website=jnanapravaha.org|publisher=jnanapravaha.org|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref>. He was the lecturer on Vallabh Vedanta at the 91st session of the Indian philosophical congress held in February 2017 at the [[Sanchi University of Buddhist-Indic Studies]] in [[Madhya Pradesh]], India<ref>{{cite web|title=91st Session of Indian philosophy Congress|url=http://indianphilosophicalcongress.in/Files/91st_IPC_Second_Circular.pdf |publisher=indianphilosophicalcongress|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Day 2 News - 91st Session of Indian philosophy Congress|url=http://tipc.sanchiuniv.org.in/dnlds/pr13thFeb2017eng.pdf|website=sanchiuniv.org.in|publisher=Sanchi University|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref>.
Pandit [[Jasraj]] has done extensive research in [[Haveli Sangeet]] under Shyam Manohar Goswami to create numerous innovative ''[[bandish]]'' (composition)<ref>{{cite news|title=A custom of culture|url=http://www.thehindu.com/mp/2004/12/01/stories/2004120100800300.htm|accessdate=25 July 2017|work=The Hindu|agency=The Hindu|issue=Online edition of India's National Newspaper|publisher=The Hindu|date=1 December 2004}}</ref>.

நாக ஆலயம் | image = Snake Temple, Penang.jpg | caption = Front view of Snake Temple | alt = | map_type = Malaysia | map_caption = Location in Malaysia | other_names = | proper_name = | country = [[Malaysia]] | state = [[Penang]] | district = [[Bayan Lepas]] | locale = | elevation_m = | deity = | festivals= | architecture = [[China|Chinese]] | temple_quantity = | monument_quantity= | inscriptions = | year_completed = 1850 | creator = [[Qingshui (monk)|Chor Soo Kong]] (祖師公) | website = }} The '''Snake Temple''' ({{zh|s=蛇庙|p=Shé Miào|poj=Tsuâ-biō}},Tamil:நாக ஆலயம், Nāka ālayam) is situated in [[Sungai Kluang]], [[Bayan Lepas]], [[Southwest Penang Island]], [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]] and is perhaps the only [[temple]] of its kind in the world. The temple is filled with the smoke of burning [[incense]] and a variety of [[pit viper]]s. The [[Viperidae|viper]]s are believed to be rendered harmless by the sacred smoke, but as a safety precaution, the [[snakes]] have also been de-venomed but still have their [[fangs]] intact. Visitors are warned against picking up the [[reptiles]] and placing them on their bodies to take pictures. Local devotees believe the temple's snake population comes there of its own accord.http://www.malaysiasite.nl/snaketempleng.htm{{cite web|url=http://www.penang.ws/penang-attractions/penang-snake-temple.htm#|title=Penang Snake Temple|work=penang.ws}} The temple was built about 1850 in memory of [[Qingshui (monk)|Chor Soo Kong]] (祖師公), by a [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] [[monk]]. Chor Soo Kong (also known as Qingshui) was born in China with the surname Tan (陳昭應 or Tan Chhiau-eng) in China during the Song Dynasty (960-1279). He was serious about seeking spiritual attainment and was ordained at an early age. According to legend, Chor Soo Kong was also a healer and sometimes gave shelter to the snakes of jungle. When he died at age 65 after a lifetime of good deeds, he was awarded the honorific title Chor Soo, that of an eminent figure revered generation after generation. After the construction of the temple, snakes reportedly appeared by themselves. The temple was originally called the "Temple of the Azure Cloud" in honor of the beauty of Penang's sky. Believers from as far away as [[Singapore]] and [[Taiwan]] come to pray in the temple on Chor Soo Kong's birthday (the sixth day of the first lunar month). The temple was featured during the 8th leg of [[The Amazing Race 16]]. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Édouard Dujardin | image = Édouard Dujardin by Vallotton.jpg | image_caption = Portrait of Édouard Dujardin by [[Félix Vallotton]] | birth_date = 10 November 1861 | birth_place = [[Saint-Gervais-la-Forêt]] | death_date = {{d-da|31 October 1949|10 November 1861}} | occupation = [[Novelist]], writer}}
'''Édouard Dujardin''' (10 November 1861 – 31 October 1949) was a French writer, one of the early users of the [[Stream of consciousness (narrative mode)|stream of consciousness]] literary technique, exemplified by his 1888 novel ''[[Les Lauriers sont coupés]].''
==Biography== Édouard Émile Louis Dujardin was born in [[Saint-Gervais-la-Forêt]], Loir-et-Cher, and was the only child of Alphonse Dujardin, a sea captain. [[Stephane Mallarmé]] described him as "the offspring of an old sea-dog and a Brittany cow".<ref name=ELS>[[Edward Lucie-Smith|Lucie-Smith, Edward.]] (1972) ''Symbolist Art''. London: [[Thames & Hudson]], p. 58. {{ISBN|0500201250}}</ref> He was educated at the ''[[Lycée Pierre Corneille (Rouen)|Lycée Pierre Corneille]]'' in Rouen.<ref name="LyCo6">[http://lgcorneille-lyc.spip.ac-rouen.fr/spip.php?article6 Lycée Pierre Corneille de Rouen – History]</ref>
Dujardin became editor of the journal ''Revue Indépendente'' in 1886, and it was in this journal that his first works were published. His association with this journal resulted in it being termed an "important voice for the symbolists" ([[Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center]] 2004).
When his parents died, Dujardin was the sole heir to their fortune, and he used some of this money to finance the plays ''Antonia'' in 1891 and ''Le Chevalier Du Passé'' in 1882.
His literary works are extensive and include numerous plays, poems and novels. Dujardin also produced works of literary and social criticism and reminiscence. [[James Joyce]] claimed his style of interior monologue owed its influence to works by Dujardin. He continued his involvement with journalism throughout his life and this resulted in numerous disputes with authorities, including charges of treason, though he was never convicted.
Dujardin had expensive and lavish tastes for clothing which was deemed "dandyish" for his time, and was known to frequent Parisian night life. His many dalliances with women were noted and he had had numerous relationships with actresses, models and other glamorous women. Dujardin was also known to have many female friends involved in the arts and he supported some of them financially.
His frivolous lifestyle eventually reduced his finances so he began numerous financial ventures, including gambling and real estate. He also offered his services to periodicals for marketing and advertising campaigns. It was here that the police noticed an article compiled by Dujardin which resulted in a jail sentence, though it was later remitted.
In 1885 Dujardin and [[Téodor de Wyzewa]]<ref>'Téodor de Wyzewa' was the adopted name of Polish-born Theodore Etienne Wyzewski, Harrison C, Wood P., Gaiger J. ''Art in Theory 1815–1900'' Blackwell, {{ISBN|0-631-20066-5}}-page 1003.</ref> initiated the ''[[Revue Wagnérienne]]'', imitating [[Félix Fénéon]] and his ''[[Revue Indépendante]]'' which had first been published the year before. This annual journal, dedicated to the work of the German composer [[Richard Wagner]], ran for three issues, from 1885 to 1887.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb32861731q/date.r=la+revue+wagn%C3%A9rienne.langFR|title=Revue wagnérienne / [directeur-gérant : Édouard Dujardin] - 3 Years available - Gallica|website=gallica.bnf.fr|language=EN|access-date=2018-12-03}}</ref> In 1886 Dujardin and Fénéon joined forces under the banner of a new improved ''Revue Indépendante''. One of the innovations at this time was that the ''Revue'' started having small exhibitions in its rooms.
Dujardin married a woman named Germaine in 1893 and they later separated in 1901. They did not divorce until 1924 when he married Marie Chenou, a woman thirty years his junior.
In May 1922 he attended the [[International Congress of Progressive Artists]] and signed the "Founding Proclamation of the Union of Progressive International Artists".<ref name="Review">{{cite web |last1=van Doesburg |first1=Theo |title=De Stijl, “A Short Review of the Proceedings [of the Congress of International Progressive Artists], Followed by the Statements Made by the Artists’ Groups” (1922) |url=https://modernistarchitecture.wordpress.com/2010/10/22/de-stijl-%E2%80%9Ca-short-review-of-the-proceedings-of-the-congress-of-international-progressive-artists-followed-by-the-statements-made-by-the-artists%E2%80%99-groups%E2%80%9D-1922/ |website=modernistarchitecture.wordpress.com |publisher=Ross Lawrence Wolfe |accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref>
Dujardin was an advocate of the [[Christ myth theory]].<ref>[[Joseph McCabe|McCabe, Joseph]]. (1950). ''A Rationalist Encyclopedia: A Book of Reference on Religion, Philosophy, Ethics, and Science''. Watts. p. 334</ref><ref>Weaver, Walter P. (1999). ''The Historical Jesus in the Twentieth Century: 1900-1950''. Trinity Press International. p. 300. {{ISBN|1-56338-280-6}}</ref> He wrote the book ''Ancient History of the God Jesus'' (1938). He fathered two children, lived a peaceful life during his old age and died aged 88 years old on 31 October 1949.
